text: The shifting lights from the odd passing car play over th faces of MR. and MRS. PRESCOTT, a pleasant-looking couple their late thirties, dressed up for a night out. Mr. Pres drives them along a dark hilly two-lane highway.
Why do they always put braces on  teenage girls at the exact moment  when they're the most self-conscious  about their appearance?
Pause.
I don't know.
UP AHEAD, near the top of the oncoming hill, a RED PICKUP TRUCK is poking its nose out of the short exit lane.
Tom --
I see him...
The PICKUP LURCHES into the road, with not nearly enough  time to spare.
Tom!
Jesus!
Mr. Prescott swerves OVER the DOUBLE SOLID WHITE LINE and clears the truck as -- Another pair of HEADLIGHTS from an oncoming truck RISES U over the HILL directly in FRONT of them --
(Screams) Tom!
Mr. Prescott's FOOT STOMPS on the BRAKE. We BLACK OUT and there is the SOUND of a terrible CRASH.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE PRESCOTTS' FRONT DOOR. NIGHT

text: The SHADOW of a big man looms up onto the front door. A b finger RINGS the BELL. A moment. AMY, a thirteen-year-old baby-sitter with braces, opens t door and looks up. In the b.g. we see TWO CHILDREN, SAMMY (Samantha) and TERRY PRESCOTT, in their pajamas, lying on their stomachs in the living room, watching television. S is eleven. Terry is eight. REVERSE: DARRYL, the SHERIFF, a portly fellow with glasse and a mustache, looks down at AMY.
Hello, Amy.
(Puzzled) Hi, Darryl.
(Thinking) Amy, would you please tell the kids  you'll be right back, and then shut  the door and come outside to talk to  us for a minute?
OK. (To kids) Be right back, you guys!
You're not supposed to go out, Amy.
She's going to smoke a cigarette.
AMY closes the door and looks expectantly up at Darryl. D doesn't know how to start.
CREDITS BEGIN OVER a blustery April day. The steeple of t little white church stands out against the sharp blue sky

It's a small church and a small congregation, but it's fu There's a CHOIR of mostly SENIOR CITIZENS arrayed in the  back. TWO CLOSED CASKETS are laid out in front of the  MINISTER, a fiftyish woman with thick glasses and salt-an pepper hair, who is giving a eulogy MOS. Among the mourners in the second row sit Terry and Sammy, both redeyed, and uncomfortable in their dress-up clothes Their Aunt Ruth, a pinch-faced woman in her forties, sits next to them. Sammy and Terry are holding hands tightly. Terry wipes hi eyes with his free hand. The Minister addresses her remarks to the children. Sammy hanging on the Minister's every word; Terry is shifting h eyes and his seat as if it will kill him to sit still ano minute.

head_text.subj: EXT. SCOTTSVILLE CEMETERY. SIXTEEN YEARS LATER. DAY

text: On the beautiful hill overlooking the beautiful windy gre country, SAMMY, twenty-seven years old now, puts flowers her parents' graves with quick, practiced movements. She is a nice-looking young woman of a neat appearance, s from primness by an elusive, pleasantly flustered quality An unsuccessfully neat person. She is dressed in office  clothes -- white blouse, dark skirt, high heels, light  raincoat over everything. She picks out a couple of weeds and then bows her head and closes her eyes. CREDITS END.

Scottsville is a small town. Main Street. Run-down old st next to a new bank, a couple of chain stores, a few  restaurants of varying ambitions. Civil War statue. World War I statue. World War II statue. Residential streets  wandering away from Main Street up and down hills. You kn there's a minimall somewhere nearby. A fair amount of act during the daytime. SAMMY'S CAR pulls up across the street from where an eigh year-old BOY in a secondhand baseball jacket and a school knapsack is waiting at the curb. This is her son, RUDY. S calls out the car window.
Rudy, come on! I'm really late!
Rudy hurries across the street and gets in the car, sling his knapsack into the backseat.
How was school?
Stupid.
Why do you say that?
We're supposed to write a story for  English homework, but they didn't  tell us what it's supposed to be  about.
What do you mean?
I mean they didn't tell us what it's  supposed to be about. They said do  whatever you want.
So what's wrong with that?
Nothing. I just think it's  unstructured.
(Smiles) Well, I'm sure you'll be able to  think of something. If you can't,  I'll help you.
Sammy stops the car outside a heavily THICKETED DRIVEWAY  (CAROL'S HOUSE), and RUDY gets out.
Don't forget your backpack.
Rudy returns to take his knapsack out of the back.
It's not a backpack, it's a knapsack.
Don't forget your knapsack.
Rudy hoists his knapsack out of the back.
Give me a kiss.
Rudy gives her a kiss and puts his arms around her and  squeezes her neck. He withdraws, slams the door. As Sammy DRIVES AWAY, he sl up the long twisting driveway.

Sammy gets out of her car, which is parked in one of the  half dozen spaces in the little parking lot allocated for bank employees. She hurries toward the employees' entrance, fixing her sk as she goes.
Sammy hurries down the clean hallway in the back past MAB a pleasant-faced fellow employee.
Guess who's been asking for you?
Oh no, really?
Mabel nods and passes by. SAMMY KNOCKS on a big door that says "Manager" and has ha the letters of the previous branch manager's name taken o it.
(Inside) Yeah, come in!

Sammy swings open the door. BRIAN EVERETT, the new branch manager, is unpacking a box. Sammy is surprised to see he in his early thirties and very good-looking in a boyish s of way; he wears shirt-sleeves and tie, and a wedding rin
Mr. Everett?
Yeah: Brian.
Brian. Hi. I'm Samantha Prescott --  I'm the lending officer?
Yeah, hi, how are you? Come on in.  Sit down.
Sammy comes into the office and sits.
I am so sorry I was late...
Yeah, we missed you before...
I got held up. Believe me, it is not  something I make a habit of...
I'm sure it's not. Actually -- could  you just, could you close that door  for me? Thanks.
Sammy gets up and closes the door.
Sammy sits in front of Brian's desk. Brian is behind the  desk listening.

-- so I always just run out at 3:15  to pick him up and then run him real  quick over to the sitter's house.  Anyway, Larry never minded about it  and I was just hoping it would be OK  with you too...
Well -- Samantha -- I realize that  Scottsville is not exactly a major  banking center...
No it's not...

No -- I know it's not... But it's  kind of a personal challenge to me  to see what we can do to bring local  service up to the same kinds of  standards we'd be trying to meet if  we were the biggest branch in the  state. And that means I don't want  anybody running out at 3:15 or 3:30,  or whenever the bus happens to come  in that day. Now is there anybody  else who can pick your son up after  school? Does your husband work in  the area? Do you --
Oh -- No -- Rudy Sr. isn't "on the  scene." So to speak.
Well, I can give you a couple of  days to make some other arrangement,  but...

Well -- Brian? I understand what  you're saying, and I think it's great.  I do. Because there's a lot of things  around here that could use some  attention. Believe me. But I've  honestly been meeting that bus every  day for four years now and it really  does take just fifteen minutes, and  if I take the time out of my lunch  hour...
I'd really prefer it if you would  make some other arrangement. OK?
(Brightly) I'll do my best...!
Brian kicks back in his chair and puts his hands behind h head.
How old's your son?
He's eight.
That's a terrific age.
Sammy and Rudy drive home in silence. The orange sunlight flickers through the trees and onto their faces as they d along.
The same house that Sammy grew up in, with sixteen years' more wear on it. Sammy's car swings expertly by the mailbox, and Rudy reac half his body out of the passenger window and gets the ma
Sammy comes into the house carrying two bags of groceries Rudy follows, looking through the mail. Sammy passes thro the house and goes into the kitchen.
You got a letter from Uncle Terry.
What?!
Her whole face lights up and she grabs the letter. She te it open and reads it with growing excitement.

Sammy opens her FILE DRAWER. Inside are tax files, househ files, miscellaneous files. She puts Terry's letter away in a very full file marked " Correspondence." The folder is stuffed with other letters on all different kinds of stationery from all over the  country, all from Terry.
Sammy and Rudy are eating dinner. It's a biggish house fo just two people.
Whose room is he gonna stay in?

He can stay in the little room. (Pause) But you know what? He's not going to  live here. He's only gonna stay for  a little while... And it's OK if you  don't remember him, because you were  only six the last time he was here...  But it'll be nice if you got a chance  to get to know each other a little  bit. Don't you think?
Rudy looks worried and doesn't answer.
Rudy is on the floor, writing in his school composition  notebook. Sammy comes downstairs.
Rudy? Would it distract you if I put  on some music?
No.
She puts on a CD, sits down and picks up a book. She look at Rudy, who is writing away.
Did you think of a story?
Uh huh.
What's it about?
My father.
Pause.
What about your father?
It's just a made-up story about him.
Can I read it when you're done?
It's not very good.
Don't say that.
Rudy keeps writing.
Sammy is smoking a cigarette and drinking a glass of wine and reading Rudy's story. It upsets her.

Sammy sits on the edge of her bed, not dialing the phone. She catches a glimpse of herself in her parents' floor-le mirror with the worn, heavy wooden frame. Against her bet judgment she picks up the phone and dials.
Sammy and BOB STEEGERSON are eating dinner at Dawson's, t only fancy restaurant in town. Bob is in his mid-thirties Realtor, a decent, ordinary guy.

Anyway, Bob, it's sort of this  adventure story, and Rudy's father  is this secret agent or something,  working for the government... And it  just made me feel weird. You know?  Because I never really say much to  him about Rudy Sr., because I don't  know what to say. And I don't know  whether I should just let him imagine  whatever he wants to imagine, or  whether I should sit him down sometime  and tell him, you know, that his  father is not such a nice person.  You know?
Well... I don't know, Sammy. What  have you told him already?

Not much. He knows I don't have the  highest opinion of him. And he knows  I don't want to see him or know  anything about him, ever. But I tried  to keep it kind of neutral. Anyway...  I could go into a lot more detail,  believe me.
Well... It's an interesting problem.  But I don't really know what to tell  you... It's a little outside my  personal field of expertise...
All right.
I'd be glad to give it some thought...
OK.
He is smiling at her.
What?
Nothing... I'm just glad to see you...  I'm glad you called me.
I bet you were surprised...!
Um -- a little.
Bob drains his wineglass. Sammy cuts at her steak.
Sammy and Bob lie in Bob's bed, a few minutes after havin made love. They are very far away from each other, but tr with difficulty not to let on.
I should get going...
Really?
Yeah... I've got the baby-sitter...  But... Thanks for a lovely evening.
Oh. Thank you.
She kisses him. She tries to make it sexy, but he's not i it anymore and he politely restricts the kissing.
Sammy stands in her slip brushing her teeth in front of t mirror. She brushes vigorously, looking at herself while brushes.
The corner window of a grim little apartment building on very grim street in a grim little city.

A tiny apartment with a bed, chair, table, fridge, and no much else. One window has a broken pane and an old sheet  neatly thumbtacked over it to keep the wind out. TERRY PRESCOTT comes in. He is twenty-five years old: a r mess with a certain natural appeal. He wears old jeans, v old hiking boots, and a lumberjack-style coat. He takes a wool hat off his head. His hair is longish and dirty. SHEILA SADLER is sitting at the table by the fridge. She barely eighteen, frail and damaged.
Hey, Terry.
Hey.
Terry looks at her and smiles encouragingly. She smiles b
Where'd you get the hat?
Oh, I got it on the street for a  dollar.
It's nice.
Well, you know, it's pretty much  your standard woolen hat.
Yeah, I had a very similar reaction  to it.
Sheila looks away. Silence.
Can I get that money from you?
Yeah. Sorry.
As she opens her purse, Terry takes a few vague steps tow her. She takes out a tiny hippie-ish woven wallet and giv Terry all the money in it: a twenty and two ones.
Is that all you have?
Yeah.
Can you borrow some cash from your  brother?
Um, yeah, but that would involve  speaking to him.
Well, I'm definitely gonna be gone  for a couple of days at least, Sheila.
Why do you have to stay so long?
Because my sister is not a bank, you  know? I can't just show up and ask  her for --
You seem to think my brother's a  bank!
Oh Sheila can we just cut out the  puerile crap?! I'll be back just as  soon as I can. OK? I am not the kind  of man that everyone says I am.
I know you're not.
I'll call you tonight.
Pause.
Don't you wanna tell me you love me?
I love you.
That was really convincing.
Well... I think after this is over  you should seriously consider moving  back home.
(Short laugh) Oh, yeah.
(Gives up) All right...
You gonna call tonight?
Definitely.
She puts her arms around him and holds on.
Wide open shot of hilly country and a big sky overhead. A GREYHOUND BUS drives into the shot along the curve of the highway.

Terry is seated on the toilet seat in the cramped bathroo smoking a joint. He takes a huge hit and holds it in for long as humanly possible. He blows out what's left, takes another equally huge hit and holds it in.
The BUS WHOOSHES along a smaller, heavily wooded roller- coaster road.

Terry looks out the window at the passing scenery. The  sunlight flickers on his face. POV TERRY: The bus rolls past the hilltop cemetery. Terry shifts uncomfortably in his seat. POV TERRY: THE "WELCOME TO SCOTTSVILLE" SIGN whizzes by.  Houses start dotting the side of the road. Terry starts getting very agitated.
Terry stands at one end of Main Street, backpack over his shoulder, as the BUS DRIVES OFF. He looks around at the t going about its Saturday afternoon business.

Loud country-western music is blaring as Sammy, wearing a apron, sets a big vase of flowers on the kitchen table an hurries to the oven. There are also cookies, a pie, evide of massive fancy cooking. She puts on her oven mitts and  takes a lasagna out of the oven, as the phone rings. She  picks up.
(Into phone) Hello?... TERRY!...
Sammy practically bursts out the front door. She has chan into nice clothes.
Terry secrets himself in a small dark alley. He takes out his carefully wrapped half joint and lights it. SMOKING, looks at the sunlit slant of street beyond the alley.

head_text.subj: EXT. MAIN STREET. A FEW MOMENTS LATER

text: Terry, fairly well stoned, walks along Main Street. A ski man emerges from his hardware store to greet Terry and sh hands. Terry says "Hi," but keeps on walking. He passes s other people. He almost runs right into SHERIFF DARRYL, sixteen years f and grayer.
Whoa there!
Sorry.
The Sheriff recognizes Terry and breaks into a big smile.
God damn! Terry Prescott! How you  doin'? Gimme a cuddle!
The Sheriff gives Terry a big bear hug. Terry is wasted a selfconscious but smiling. He pats the Sheriff's back.
How you doin', Darryl?
Which way you headed?
I'm just goin' to see Sammy at  Dawson's...
Can I walk with you a little?
Sure, yeah --
So Sammy says you been out in  Alaska...?
Yeah, I was workin' out there for a  little while...

head_text.subj: EXT. MAIN STREET. A FEW MOMENTS LATER

text: The Sheriff walks along with Terry. Terry, very self-cons about smelling like pot, fumbles to light a cigarette. Th Sheriff does not seem to notice.
-- Sammy says she's gettin' postcards  from all across the country.
Yeah, I've been all over the place...
They stop outside Dawson's.
Well, it's good to have you back  here, I'll tell you that.
Thanks, Darryl. Keep enforcing the  peace.
Well, that'll be a little harder now  that you're home, but I'll do what I  can.
No, man, I'm reformed.
Oh, yeah. Good to see you, kid.
Thanks, Darryl.

Darryl walks away. Terry stands outside the restaurant lo for Sammy. Behind him in the restaurant Sammy is sitting at a table, talking to the waitress. She sees Terry and gets up immediately, smiling like craz as she threads her way through the tables toward the door Terry turns and sees her. He breaks into a big smile, tos his cigarette and goes into the restaurant. Through the w we see them make their way toward each other. Sammy throws her arms around him. He hugs her back with a big involuntary smile as the GLASS DOOR slowly CLOSES.

head_text.ToD: AT THEIR TABLE. A FEW MOMENTS LATER

text: Terry is studying the menu, over-intently. Sammy is beami at him.
Sorry about yesterday --
I don't care --
I was studying the bus description...  and I just... I got on the wrong bus --  I mean I missed my stop --
I don't care, Terry. I'm just so  glad to see you...!
I'm glad to see you too, Sammy. Um...  are you coming from work?
Um, no, it's Saturday...
Yeah, no, it's just... you're dressed  so formally...
Oh. No. You know, I just thought I'd --  You know I thought it was a special  occasion... which it is...
No, it's good. I thought I'd dress  up too.
He gestures to his shitty clothes.
That's OK. You look fine.
(A strange,  unsuccessful joke) Yeah, this is the haute cuisine of  garments.
What?
Nothing, nothing... Um... So how are  you?
I'm fine.
How's Rudy?
We're fine, Terry. How are you? (Pause) I mean --
Yeah...
-- Where have you been lately, Terry?
-- I know, I haven't been --
I got a postcard from you from  Alaska...?
Yeah, I was up there for a while...
But that was in the Fall, Terry...
Yeah, I know I've been out of touch...
I was a little worried. (Pause) I mean --
Oh, I been a lotta different places...  Um... I went down to Florida for a  while... I was doing some work in  Orlando... I've been all over the  place.
Well... I just wish you would have  let me know you were OK...
Yeah. I didn't realize it'd been so  long...
He looks around the restaurant.
(Beaming again) Are you gonna stay in town for a  while?
Well, I don't know... I got all these  things I gotta do back in Worcester...
Oh...
...Yeah, so I'm probably not gonna  be able to stay more than a day or  so...
Oh... Well... That's all right...!
...I'm kind of trying to keep to a  schedule of sorts. It's a long and  worthy story but I won't trouble you  with it right now.
He twists around and looks all over the restaurant. She  watches him.
Are you expecting someone?
Who would I be expecting here?
You just keep looking around, that's  all.
No, I was just wondering if we could  get some more refreshments, actually.
He laughs. Looks down. Silence. He looks up at her.

I've actually got to confess to you,  Sammy... that the reason you may not  have heard from me for a little while  is that I've been kind of unable to  write... on account of the fact that  I was in jail for a little while.
You were what?
A couple of people in the restaurant look at them. Terry  notices but Sammy does not.
Well, I did a little time, I guess,  in Florida. For, uh, just for  bullshit...
What?!
It was just bullshit...
What did you do?
I didn't do anything. Does it occur  to you that maybe I was wronged?
No!
Well, could I please --
Oh my God! --
Would you please let me --
-- What happened?!

I got into a fight in a bar down in  Florida. Which I was not the one who  instigated it, at all. But they worked  up all this bullshit against me and  they threw me in the pen for three  months. I didn't write you because I  didn't want you to get all upset  about it. I just figured you'd figure  I was on the road for a little while.  I know it was stupid and I'm sorry.  I really didn't mean to make you  worry. But you know what? I can't  run around all the time doin' stuff  or not doin' stuff because it's gonna  make you worry! Because then I come  back here, and I tell you about my  fuckin'... traumas, and I get this  wounded little "I've Let You Down"  bullshit, over and over again, and  it really just -- cramps me! Like I  just want to get out from under it!...  And here I am back in this fuckin'  hole explaining myself to you again!
OK -- Can you please stop cursing at  me?

I mean, I realize I'm in no position  to, uh, basically say anything, ever --  But it's not like I'm down there in  some redneck bar in Florida having  an argument with some stripper's  boyfriend and I suddenly think, "Hey!  Maybe this'd be a good time to really  stick it to Sammy and get myself  locked up for a few months."
I'm sorry.
Me too, man. I mean "welcome home."
Hey -- You don't write me for six  months, I have no idea where you are --
I'm sorry --
-- I don't know if you're alive or  dead --
I'm sorry --
-- and then you show up out of nowhere  and tell me you were in jail?
I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I'm sorry,  Sammy, I'm really sorry...!
The patrons are all either looking at them or trying not look. Silence.
Sammy...
What?
Um... I'm in the midst of a slight  predicament...
What do you need? Money?

Um... Yeah... I'm broke. I gotta get  back to Worcester tomorrow. I got  this girl there, and she's kind of  in a bad situation...? I just need  to borrow some money. Whatever you  can spare. (Pause) I'll pay you back... I'll pay you  back, man.
I really wish Mom was here.
So do I, man.
Nobody knows what to do with you.
I know how they feel, man.
Silence, except for the sounds of the restaurant.
Terry? Can I ask you something?
Sure.
(With some difficulty) Well -- I mean, do you ever go to  church anymore?
Come on, Sammy, can we not talk about  that shit?
Do you?
Um -- No, Sammy. I don't.
Can you tell me why not?
Um, yeah. Because I think it's  ridiculous.
Well -- can you tell me without like,  denigrating what I believe in?
Because I think it's primitive, OK?  I think it's a fairy tale.
Well -- I mean, have you ever  considered that maybe that's part of  what's making things so difficult  for you?
No.

-- That you've lost hold of -- well,  not just your religious feeling, but  lost hold of any kind of anchor, any  kind of trust in anything... I mean  no wonder you drift around so much.  What could ever stop you? How would  you ever know if you had found the  right thing?
Well, uh, I'm not really looking for  anything, man. I'm just, like, trying  to get on with it.
The WAITRESS approaches with their salads.
Here we go...
She sets them down on the table. SAMMY and TERRY Thank you. The WAITRESS leaves. Silence. Terry picks at his salad. S doesn't touch hers. She watches him miserably.
Terry watches while Sammy inserts her card in the ATM and punches in her code. Terry waits. She punches in $300. Th machine grinds out her cash. She gives him the money.
Thank you, Sammy... I'm really gonna  pay this back.
She takes her card back and puts it back in her wallet.
Sammy and Terry get in the car. Sammy isn't saying anythi
Where we going?
To pick up Rudy.
She puts on her glasses and her seat belt. She won't look him.
Well... do you not even want me to  visit now? 'Cause I can catch the  bus at five o'clock if that's what  you want.

Well, of course I want you to visit,  you idiot! I've been looking forward  to seeing you more than anything!  I've been telling everyone I know  that you were coming home! I cleaned  the whole fucking house so it would  look nice for you! I thought you  were gonna stay for at least a few  days! It didn't occur to me that you  were just broke again. I wish you  would have just sent me an invoice!
She stops. Terry is now totally contrite.
Terry sits in the tub. Water drips from the faucet. He is staring blankly up at the pristine blue-and-white tiled w and the neatly folded matching towels.
Sammy and Rudy are in the living room. Rudy is playing wi a Game Boy type game. In the b.g., TERRY is dialing the P He looks clean and shaved, his hair is neatly combed.
(Into phone) Hi, is that Malcolm?... Hi, this is  Terry Prescott?... I been trying to  get ahold of Sheila and there's no  answer, and I was just wondering if  she -- She what?...
He sits down.
(Into phone) When?... Well -- Is she all right?...  Well, could I talk to her?... Well,  could you give her a message that I --
CLICK. He is hung up on. He slowly HANGS UP. Sammy notices that something's wrong. He looks at her fro across the room.
That girl I'm with tried to kill  herself.
What?
She tried to kill herself.
Terry is sitting on the bed, addressing an envelope to SH He puts the $300 in the ENVELOPE and seals it. He sees Sa standing in the doorway. He starts to unlace his boots.
Do you have everything you need?
I think so.
Sammy comes into the room and sits next to him. He is ver busy with his laces.
What are you going to do?
I don't know. Send the money I guess.
Maybe you should stay home for a  little while, Terry.
Yeah, maybe that'd be a good idea.
He starts crying. Sammy pats him.
A bright, clear, blue-skied Sunday morning in Scottsville Inside the little white church they're singing.

People are filing out of the church. We also see a couple the bank employees, including BRIAN and his very pretty s months' PREGNANT wife, NANCY. We find SAMMY and RUDY. Sam is chatting to some neighbors. Rudy is bored out of his m waiting for her.
Terry is lying on the sofa, smoking, with his feet up and boots on, watching Sunday morning TV. On the coffee table are his dirty ashtray, dirty bowl and spoon, Rice Krispie box and a milk carton.
Crickets buzz loudly outside the house.
Sammy, in her bathrobe, comes down the stairs into the li room. Terry is on the sofa playing with Rudy's Game Boy. barely looks up when she speaks to him.
I'm going to bed. Do you have  everything you need?
Yeah. Thanks.
Good night.
Good night.
Pause.
Terry, I'm really glad you're home.
Terry tries to smile at her.
Yeah, me too, Sammy.
He goes back to his game. She hesitates, then heads back the stairs.

Sammy, Terry and Rudy sit at the kitchen table. Sammy is  dressed for work. Rudy is dressed for school. Terry is al fully dressed, drinking the last dregs of a mug of coffee He is tired, but listening to Sammy very carefully, as if receiving difficult and critical instructions.

OK. So we'll drop Rudy off at the  bus, then all you have to do is drop  me off at the bank, and just pick  Rudy up at 3:30 in front of town  hall, and drive him over to Carol's  house. And that's it. She's on Harvey  Lane, right past where the Dewitts  used to live.
OK.
Rudy knows where she lives.
Terry glances at Rudy, then back at Sammy.
OK.
Sammy walks past MABEL'S DESK, carrying a big stack of fi She drops three of them on the desk. MABEL is typing away her PC. The colors are a garish PURPLE background with GR letters.
God, Mabel, don't those colors hurt  your eyes?
Oh no, they keep me fresh.
Sammy proceeds down the hall and into --
Brian is at his desk, busy working between stacks of pape She knocks on the open door.
Yeah! (Looks up) Hi, Sammy. What can I do for you?
Um, Brian? Did you want us to turn  this time sheet in at the end of the  day, or do you want it at the end of  the week...?
Oh, yeah, end of the day'll be fine.
Seems like an awful lot of extra  paperwork...
Brian hesitates, shrugs and smiles.
I like paperwork.
Sammy looks at him with a blank smile.
Sammy sits down at her desk and notices the time: 3:30. S reaches for the phone, then decides not to call.

The CLOCK on the front of the TOWN HALL reads 3:31. The SCHOOL BUS pulls up across from the town hall and  disgorges a handful of kids. Rudy comes out with his knap looking around... POV RUDY: Terry, across the street, sits on the hood of  Sammy's car, smoking. Rudy walks over to him.
You showed up.
Looks that way.
Terry and Rudy drive in silence. Terry glances at Rudy.
Put on your seat belt.
It pushes on my neck.
What?
It pushes on my neck. It's  uncomfortable.
Well, when somebody slams into us  and you go sailin' through the  windshield, that's liable to be  uncomfortable too. So put on your  seat belt.
Rudy puts on his seat belt.
Mom's parents died in a car accident.
I know. They're my parents too.
They are?
Well, yeah. Your mom is my sister.
Yeah, I know.
So that means we have the same  parents.
Oh yeah.
They drive in silence for a moment. Terry glances down at Rudy.
Sammy, laden with files, plops down at her desk as Mabel passing by. Mabel puts a phone message down in front of h
Um -- Carol just called. She said  Terry and Rudy never showed up at  her house?
You've got to be kidding me.
A MOMENT LATER: Brian, talking to an employee, sees Sammy across the bank, hurrying out the employees' exit.
Hey, Sammy?
Sammy doesn't hear and exits.
Terry and Rudy are banging nails with RAY, a young guy Te age. Terry, hammering with swift, accurate blows, glances and watches Rudy for a second. Rudy is hammering away wit no great skill.
Hey. Look.
He moves Rudy's hand down toward the end of the handle.
You hold it further down, you're  gonna get a lot more power. You should  be able to put that nail down with  two or three hits. Look:
With two swift strokes he drives the nail flush into the  wood.
Try it.
That's not the way I hold it.
Well, the way you hold it is wrong.
Why can't I just do it my own way?
Terry looks at him unsympathetically for a moment.
(Shrugs) You can.
He goes back to work. Rudy resumes hammering. After a mom he switches his grip and starts hammering Terry's way. Te looks up and watches him.

head_text.subj: EXT. IN FRONT OF ORRIN'S HOUSE. A MOMENT LATER

text: Sammy pulls up, fast, and gets out of the car. Hearing th hammering from the backyard, she walks quickly around the side of the house and stops short when she sees Rudy hamm happily away with Terry and Ray. She watches them working, unobserved, with mixed annoyanc and relief, and finally with quiet pleasure, because it's very cheerful sight.
Half the staff has gone home. Sammy, in her coat, picks a NOTE up off her CHAIR. It reads:

head_text.subj: INT. BRIAN'S OFFICE. A MOMENT LATER

text: Sammy stands in front of Brian's desk.
Brian? Did you want to see me?
Yeah. I was kind of wondering what  happened to you today.
Oh -- Didn't Mabel -- I had a false  alarm about my son...
Yeah, I kind of thought you were  gonna work that out.
Well, I did work it out -- more or  less --
Then why're you running outta here  in the middle of the day without a  word of explanation to me, Sammy?
Brian, don't yell at me.
I'm -- I'm not yelling. I'm just  gettin' a little frustrated here.
Well Brian:
Sorry, could you close the door  please?
Sammy closes the door.
Sammy, Terry and Rudy sit at dinner. The atmosphere is li and cheerful.
...And Eddy Dwyer lives in Buffalo,  with his wife and two sons, if you  can believe it.
That is depressing.
Why?
He just never struck me as the  marrying type, that's all.
Who are you talking about?
Wild kids we used to know.
Were you a wild kid?
Not compared to your Mom.
Yeah, right.
You don't believe me?
No.
Ask her.
Mom, were you?
No comment.
Rudy is amazed. Terry looks at him like, "Told you so."
Sammy is asleep in bed.
Rudy is asleep in bed.
Terry sits at the bar, drinking beer. There are a few loc in the place, but it's pretty dead. He looks around; his  energy is too restless for the near-empty bar.

The DOOR OPENS, and TERRY COMES IN, smoking a cigarette.  He's plastered. He looks around the room. Looks at Rudy's toys. Picks up some superhero comics and sits on Rudy's b Then he spies Rudy's COMPOSITION BOOK, picks it up and st reading it.
What are you doing?
Terry looks up. Rudy is half-sitting up in bed.
Oh -- Just readin' some of your  compositions.
Why are you smoking?
Um... Because it's bad. Don't ever  do it.
I won't.
You know this used to be my room?
Yeah... (Pause) Do you want it back?
No.
Rudy is very relieved. Terry keeps reading. Rudy watches  him.
Did you fight in Vietnam?
No. I wasn't even born yet.
Were you ever in the army?
No.
My father was in the army.
I know. Unfortunately he didn't fight  in Vietnam either.
Were you friends with him?
Not really. We had some friends in  common, I guess... I didn't like him  very much.
Why not?
Well, he wasn't very likable.
Why do you say that?

I don't know. He was always -- He  always had to be better than you at  everything. You know. Like if you  were all playing basketball or  something, everybody's havin' like a  friendly game and he's like ready to  kill somebody if his team didn't  win. Or like if you told like a joke  or a story, he always had to tell a  better one? Kinda gets annoying after  a while. Plus it was pretty scummy  how he split on your mom and you...  He was a prick. Probably still a  prick. Fortunately for you though,  your mom is like, the greatest. So  you had some bad luck and you had  some good luck. (Pause) You mind if I ask you a personal  question?
I don't know.
Do you like it here? I mean, in  Scottsville?
Yeah...?
Why?
I don't know. My friends are here...  I like the scenery... I don't know.
I know, I know, but it's so... There's  nothing to do here.
Yes there is.

No there isn't, man! It's narrow.  It's dull. It's a dull, narrow town  full of dull, narrow people who don't  know anything except... what things  are like right around here. They  have no perspective whatsoever. No  scope. They might as well be living  in the nineteenth century because  they have no idea what's going on,  and if you try to tell 'em that,  they wanna fuckin' kill you.
What are you talking about?
I don't know...
Terry lies on his back and smokes.
You're a good kid.
There's a NOTE on Sammy's chair.
Sammy, just arrived at work and still in her coat, looks  down at the note.
Sammy listens to Brian.

Yeah. This doesn't apply to you  directly, Sammy, but I've noticed  that some of the employees have their  PC monitors set with all kinds of  crazy colors... Purple and polka  dots or what have you. And it's not  a big deal, but really, this is a  bank. You know? It's not really  appropriate. So I'm just asking that  people stick to a more quote unquote  normal range of colors in future...
Sammy looks at him blankly.
Like I say, it doesn't really apply  to you.
No, my computer palette's pretty  conservative.
Mabel is typing angrily at a GRAY SCREEN with BLACK LETTE Sammy walks by. Mabel is so mad she doesn't even look up.
Sammy sits agitated for a moment. She makes a decision, p up the phone and dials.
Bob is in his little realty office with two CLIENTS, a hu and wife. He picks up his RINGING PHONE.
(Into phone) Bob Steegerson.
(On phone) What are you wearing?
(Into phone) Mom?
Sammy LAUGHS.
Terry is holding a broom looking up at the ceiling. Sammy passes by and stops.
What's up?
Terry taps the broom handle against the ceiling.
Do you know you have an enormous  leak from the upstairs hall?
He pokes again. A portion of the ceiling collapses on his head in wet chunks of plaster and muck.
Um, yeah, thanks, I did.
Sammy, in front of the mirror, finishes dolling herself u for her date. O.C. we hear loud banging. Sammy puts on he earrings and goes into --
Are you guys sure you're gonna be  OK?
Yes. Yes.
Sammy approaches RUDY and TERRY. They are bent over a big nasty trench in the floorboard. There are wood shavings a greasy pipe segments all over, and black smeary smudges o the walls nearby.
What is happening here?
It's just -- The problem is that the  pipe is corroded all the way along  the length of the hall. So every  time I put in a new piece it starts  leaking further down.
Why don't I just call the plumber?
Why? He's not gonna do anything  different than what I'm doing.
(Happily) Yeah. We're making it worse!
No we're not. Shut up.
Terry yanks the wrench and a SPRAY of FILTHY WATER comes of the pipe and splatters the wallpaper and pictures and  Sammy with gritty gray water. She looks at them.
Thank you. Thank you both.
Bob and Sammy -- cleaned up and wearing a different outfi are bustling out the front door. Terry stands by.
Now, call if there's any problem,  and if I'm not there, I'm either on  my way or on my way back home.
OK.
Sammy gets into her coat. Bob opens the front door.
(To TERRY) So lights out at ten... and don't  spend the whole night watching TV.
Nice to meet you, Bob.
You too.
(To SAMMY) What's your idea of the whole night?
Two hours tops.
Bob holds the door for Sammy and smiles at her. There is  some confusion about who should go out first. Finally she goes and Bob follows. The atmosphere between them is fair awkward.
Terry and Rudy are watching TV from the sofa.
What's your feeling about Bob?
I don't really know him that well.
Terry looks at his watch.
I have bad news for you.
He picks up the remote...
...and turns off the TV. They sit there in the sudden sil
Great. What are we supposed to do  now?
Do you know how to play pool?
I've played it.
The Wild Moose is a noisy roadside bar sitting under the  stars. Terry and Rudy get out of the car. Rudy looks  apprehensive.
I don't think they let kids in there.
Well, we're not allowed to watch any  more TV, so it's this or nothing...  But if we run into any trouble, let  me do the talking.
OK.
Terry swings the door open.

POV RUDY: A lot of men and women at the bar or in booths, eating and drinking. Smoky, crowded and very loud. As he  follows Terry through the crowd various patrons notice hi some of the looks are friendly, some blank, some cold, i. what's a kid doing in here? AT THE POOL TABLE: Terry and Rudy stand side by side faci the players and waiting players gathered around the table Terry waves a few bills.
I got a hundred bucks here says me  and my nephew can beat anybody in  here. Only we gotta get the next  game 'cause he's gotta be in bed by  ten o'clock.
A MOMENT LATER: RUDY, very nervous, and the 1st Pool Play are side by side shooting for break. Terry is behind Rudy coaching him.
Just hit it nice and soft... Nice  and soft.
They hit the balls. Rudy just clips his ball and it doesn go anywhere. 1st Pool Player's ball hits the opposite ban and comes almost all the way back.
(To TERRY) Sorry.
God damn, Rudy. I thought you said  you could play.
Rudy doesn't answer. Terry winks at him. A MOMENT LATER: 1ST POOL PLAYER BREAKS -- WHACK! -- The b scatter. Nothing drops. TERRY steps up to the table, chal up his cue.
Boys, it's all over but the cryin'.

QUICK CUTS: Of Terry running the table and everyone watch Three-ball in the side. One-ball in the corner. Nine-ball off three cushions and into the corner, and the eleven-ba into the side. Rudy watches him.
Bob and Sammy sit at Bob's dining room table. The little  bachelor apartment looks pretty good. Tablecloth, candles wine, everything. Bob has just dropped a huge bombshell.
Bob... Are you serious?
Yeah.
I... I don't know what to say. I --
I mean, I know I haven't exactly  been the most... decisive... guy. In  the past... I don't know: I'm tired  of foolin' around. And I love you.
I... I'm totally... I don't know  what to say.
Well, you could always say "Yes." (Pause) Or you could think about it first.
That's it: I want to think about it.
OK... Fair enough.
Terry has sunk everything but the eight ball. He leans ov to sink it. It's a fairly easy shot. He lines it up caref and deliberately shoots it so it stops two inches from th corner pocket.
Ohhhh!

A FEW MOMENTS LATER: Terry and Rudy sit side by side watc as the 2nd Pool Player passes back and forth between them and the camera, running the table. "Oohs" and "All rights emit from the spectators. Sudden silence. Then the clack of the balls connecting. A great common GROAN goes up. RUDY looks up at Terry.
It's all yours, baby.

Rudy looks at the TABLE: The eight-ball is two inches off the corner. The cue ball is a few inches away from it. A  piece of cake, for an adult. Rudy looks deeply unconfiden He gets up and tries to line up the eight-ball. Terry is  right next to him.
Just make sure to hit it really  gentle. But firm. And hit it a little  low so you get some backspin. Don't  even hit it. Just kiss it.
A long moment.
What do you mean, kiss it?
I mean tap it. Firm but very, very  softly. And don't shoot until you  know it's going in. OK?
OK.

Everyone is relatively quiet. Rudy takes a few practice  strokes and then hits the cue ball, straight, but too sof It crawls toward the eight and taps it toward the corner, slower and slower, hangs there, and DROPS. A GENERAL "HEYYY!" GOES UP and everyone claps and cheers. Terry grabs Rudy. Rudy smiles, ecstatic.
That was great!
AT THE BAR: Darryl the SHERIFF, in his civvies, drinking pint of beer, notices Rudy and Terry. AT THE POOL TABLE: Terry picks Rudy up and turns him upsi down. Rudy laughs.
The house is dark. Terry and Rudy are walking from the ca to the house.
We creamed those guys! We creamed  them!
(Stopping suddenly) Ssh...! Don't move.
They listen. A CAR is COMING.
It's them!
They break for the door, Terry fumbling for his key. He g the door open.
Go! Go! Go!
He and Rudy run inside the house. The lights go on. BOB'S CAR pulls into the DRIVEWAY.
Rudy runs up the stairs.
Wait a minute, gimme your jacket!
Rudy tries to take his jacket off fast but gets his arm c in the sleeve. He tries to shake it off.
What are you doing?
I can't get my sleeve out...!

They HEAR Bob's CAR DOORS SLAM. Terry makes a comic panic face and leaps up the stairs two at a time. OUTSIDE THE HOUSE: Sammy waves to Bob. Bob waves back as drives off. Sammy goes to the front door, opens it: Terry and Rudy are in a giggly tangled panicked heap at t top of the stairs, shaking Rudy's arm and sleeve, frantic trying to get the jacket off. Sammy comes in. They freeze.
What is going on in here?
Um -- We were just out doing some  star-gazing, and, uh, Rudy lost track  of the time. Which I totally warned  him about. (To Rudy) You are a bad kid.
Rudy is brushing his teeth. Terry pokes his head in.
(In a low voice) Hey: I think it's OK. Just don't  tell her where we went, 'cause she'll  be really mad at me. OK?
I won't.
(Suddenly dark) Hey -- I'm not kidding, Rudy.
I won't!
Terry gives him a "You better not" look, then leaves. Rud continues brushing his teeth.
Sammy is tucking Rudy in, stroking his hair.
Did you know my Mommy used to take  me and Uncle Terry out at night to  look at the constellations?
Yeah.
Did you see that one, what's the one --  It looks like a big "W"? Cassiopeia?
Yeah.
Sammy comes out of Rudy's room, smiling. It's dark. She s a LIGHT on under TERRY'S DOOR. She walks toward it and st into the TRENCH, falling down violently.
Ow! Shit!
Terry is putting a butterfly Band-Aid on Sammy's wound. I a nasty, bloody gash, just shy of needing stitches.
I've got a great idea. Why don't you  let me call the plumber?
Do whatever you want.
Oh, does that make you mad?
No...
RAIN patters on the ROOF as Sammy LIMPS back and forth ac the room changing into her nightgown.
Terry is smoking pot with his head and shoulders stuck ou the window. RAIN FALLS on his HEAD.
Early morning. The RAIN is still falling. Only a few cars are in the employee parking lot yet.
The RAIN runs down Brian's office window. BRIAN, in a wet raincoat, turns on his light. A MOMENT LATER: Brian turns on his PC. The SCREEN lights The COLORS are a garish GREEN and ORANGE.
LATER: SAMMY and BRIAN are both on their feet. The door i closed.
Brian, get off my ass!
Excuse me?
I didn't change the colors on your  stupid computer screen.
Well, that's all you gotta say!

(On "that's") There is nothing wrong with the work  I do here. I have been doing just  fine, the whole time before you came  here -- And if you think that riding  people in this petty, ridiculous way  is the way to improve service in  this bank or anywhere else I think  you're out of your mind!
Pause.
I didn't say there was. Could I please --  Could I please -- May I respond?
No, that's really all I have to --
May I respond? (Beat) First of all, I don't appreciate  being spoken to with that kind of  language. That's not the way I talk  to you, and I'd appreciate it if you  wouldn't talk that way to me --
Well --
Second of all, if you say you didn't  change the colors on my computer  screen, then of course I accept your  answer. But you and I are gonna have  to find a way to work together --
Brian --

But that's not gonna happen with the  attitude, it's not gonna happen with  the lateness, it's not gonna happen  by fighting me every step of the way --  OK, well not you, you're not late,  but too much of that stuff goes on  around here --
I am not late and I do not have an  attitude -- Well then don't tell me  I'm late if I'm not late!
I'd really like to finish!
OUTSIDE BRIAN'S OFFICE: The whole staff is listening to t muffled raised VOICES from inside the office. MABEL especially is listening guiltily.
The rain falls on Main Street.
The rain comes down hard on Orrin's construction project. Tarps cover everything. No work today.

The rain comes down on the SHERIFF, looking through the  restaurant WINDOW at SAMMY, eating lunch alone at the cou He goes inside, shakes the rain off himself and goes over her. They start talking. We HEAR:
They were where?

The RAIN on the roof makes a sleepy, pleasant country sou TERRY is lying on the sofa, smoking a joint, watching TV, a funk. O.C. we LOUD BANGING ON THE PIPES. LATER: A YOUNG PLUMBER, about Terry's age, comes thumping down the stairs and goes into the living room, carrying h toolbox. Terry looks up at him.
OK, you're all set.
Terry glares at him. The plumber turns and goes out.
RUDY is WAITING in a doorway for Terry. He is wet and col The RAIN pours down.

Brian is showing his wife, NANCY, the bank. He is very  solicitous of her, nervously introducing her to the emplo who are not responding very warmly. Nancy is not in a war mood either; she's very testy with Brian.
This is Chuck. Chuck, this is my  wife, Nancy.
Hello.
Nice to meet you.
This is Mabel...
Hi.
Nice to meet you.
SAMMY, at her desk, watches Brian and Nancy make their  progress through the bank. Nobody is being very friendly, and Brian suddenly seems awkward and vulnerable. Brian an Nancy reach Sammy's desk.
This is Sammy, our lending officer.  Sammy, this is my wife, Nancy.
(Friendly) Hi. It's nice to meet you.
Brian -- I gotta sit down.
Sure -- Let's go in my office.
He glances nervously at Sammy as he leads Nancy away from her desk and toward his office. He murmurs something to N who responds in a low but very testy voice:
I'm fine...!
She roughly pulls her arm away from his. Sammy watches th go into his office.
Rudy trudges resolutely through the pouring rain toward t center of town. He is completely drenched.
Sammy knocks on Brian's open door.
Brian...?
Yeah.
Mom!
Sammy sees to her left, down the hallway --
Rudy!
Rudy is at the end of the hall, drenched and shivering, b cheerful.
Rudy is in the car, somewhat dried off, waiting. Sammy an Terry stand in the employee entrance doorway.
Look, I'm glad you guys are getting  along so well -- like, you have no  idea -- but if I can't rely on you  to remember to get him once a day...
You can!
-- And what are you doing taking him  to play pool in the middle of the  night, and then telling him to lie  to me about it?
Pause.
I don't know.
Terry and Rudy pull up in front of the driveway. Terry is a silent rage. The rain has let up.
Get out of the car.
What are we doing?
You're going to Carol's house and  I'm going home.
Why can't I come with you?

Because if you're such a baby you  gotta tell your Mommy about us playin'  pool when I totally asked you not  to, and I gotta listen to her shit  all day, then you're goin' to the  baby-sitter's so you can stay at the  baby house.
But I didn't tell her!
You know what? Don't even fuckin'  talk to me.
I didn't!
Just get out of the car.
He leans over Rudy roughly and pushes open the door. Rudy gets out of the car and marches down the long driveway. H bursts into tears. Terry watches him go, then drives off.
Sammy walks through the empty bank hall and into Brian's  office. Brian is at his desk.
You're working late.
How did your wife like the bank?
Oh, fine. She wasn't feeling so great.
That's too bad.
No -- I don't mean -- She's not ill.  She's just... I don't know...
Pregnant?
That's it. She's pregnant.
It can make you kind of cranky.
Yeah...
Pause.
Listen, I'm sorry we've been stepping  on each other's toes -- I -- I'm not  actually that bad a guy --
Yeah, I am too... I know you're not,  Brian, but you're driving everybody  crazy.
Well, I -- I'm just trying to do my  best here -- And I'm gettin' it from  all sides.
I know you are...
Anyway... We'll work it out...
Well... I could use a beer.
I could use a tranquilizer.
Brian and Sammy sit at a table in the corner of the dimly lit pub. It's a medium noisy place with various locals  drinking beers and eating hamburgers and chicken dinners.
Last I heard, Rudy's Dad was living  over in Auburn. But that was last  year.
Must be so tough raising a kid on  your own... Although I'm beginning  to get the idea my wife wouldn't  mind a crack at it.
Oh... It's just the hormones.
Well, no, it isn't. But never mind.
The waitress brings them two boilermakers. SAMMY and BRIAN Thanks. She leaves. Sammy and Brian pick up their shots.
Well, here's to improved employee- management relations.
Amen.
They click shot glasses and drink.
You can't judge all of Scottsville  by the people in that bank, believe  me.
Well -- Let's -- Let's not talk about  the bank.
OK.
Let's just forget about the bank for  tonight.
Good idea.
They sip their drinks, smiling. Sammy looks at him  appraisingly.
Sammy and Brian are making out in the front seat of his c This goes on for a while, getting heavier and heavier.
Sammy?
Yeah?
I want you to tell me who changed  the colors on my computer screen.
I'll never tell.
They start kissing again in the cramped space. Brian bang his head. They laugh.
We pull back and away from the car. The sodden trees spou faucets of water down on the car.
The kitchen is dark. Sammy comes in, her hair a little we and turns on the light. She goes to the telephone. There's a NOTE in Terry's handwriting:
Where were you?
Sammy jumps, startled. Terry is in the kitchen doorway.
Nowhere. I had dinner with my boss.
Kind of a late dinner, ain't it?
Yeah. How was Rudy?
Fine.
Did the plumber come?
Yes, the fucking plumber came.
Terry -- Give me a break!!!
Pause.
What's the matter with you?
Nothing. I'm just tired.
You want to smoke some pot?
No I don't. Why, you got some?
Sammy and Terry stand side by side on the porch, passing joint back and forth. It has stopped raining but the tree and roof are still dripping. The crickets are chirping lo
So... Bob asked me to marry him.
Wow. (Pause) Are you going to?
I don't know. If he'd've asked me  this time last year I would have  probably said yes. But the minute he  said it, I don't know, I felt like  somebody was trying to strangle me.
Well... bad sign.
I know. (Pause) Plus, Terry... (Whispers) I fucked my boss...!
What?
I know! And his wife is six months  pregnant.
Jesus Christ, Sammy...!
I know, I know.

He passes her the joint. She declines. He puffs away. The water drips off the porch and the crickets chirp. She put her head on his shoulder. He puts one arm around her and  puffs away with the joint in his free hand.
Terry, I'm sorry I got so mad before.  I just don't want him, you know --  terrified of "telling," if there's --
Uh, well, that's not really his  problem, Sammy.
Sammy straightens up.
Oh really? What's his problem?
His problem is that he's like totally  sheltered because you treat him like  he's three, instead of eight, so  that's how he behaves.
Oh yeah? And how do you think he  should behave?
I think he shouldn't have to run and  tell his Mommy every time he does  something she might not like, for  one thing.
Uh huh. And what do you --

(On "and") I mean I took him to play pool! It  was a little clandestine thing we  did for fun! It wasn't like a big  secret, I mean who cares? I was  actually trying to be nice to him.  But he's so freaked out that he  disobeyed your orders that he has to  fuckin' squeal on me and I have to  listen to your fuckin' shit all day  when I didn't even fuckin' do  anything!

First of all, he didn't tell me  anything: Darryl did. OK? Second of  all, I don't really give a shit if  you took him to play pool: I was mad  at you because you left him standing  at the bus stop in the rain. But no,  I don't want you telling him not to  squeal, because I don't want him put  in that position!
(Losing ground) Well... that... is a perfect example  of what I'm talking about.
You are in idiot.
They stand apart now. Silence.
Darryl told you?
Yes!
They stand there. The rain gutters drip.
Sammy, coat on, arrives at her desk and puts her purse do There's a NOTE on her CHAIR.

TRACKING SAMMY, coat off, carrying a stack of folders, as she walks from her desk, around the corner, down the hall past a couple of employees and to BRIAN'S OPEN DOOR. She  taps on it. Brian is at his desk.
Morning.
Yeah, good morning. Could you get  the door?

OUTSIDE THE OFFICE: Sammy shuts the door. MABEL and DORIS standing near the door, look at each other: i.e., Sammy's trouble again. INSIDE THE OFFICE: Sammy stands by the closed door. Brian comes out around his desk.
Listen -- I just --

Brian kisses her. She drops her folders and they make out against the door. OUTSIDE THE OFFICE: The employees click away at their PCs Mabel exchanges a quiet word with Chuck. INSIDE THE OFFICE: Brian has Sammy pressed against the wa with her skirt hiked up and is trying to get both of thei underwear out of the way. It's not so easy in their offic clothes. Sammy tears away.
Brian, that's enough.
BRIAN falls back, breathless.
OK. Sorry.

He lunges at her again. They kiss some more. OUTSIDE THE OFFICE. A MOMENT LATER: Sammy comes out of th office, more or less composed, carrying her folders. She  heads down the hall past the other employees, including M and surreptitiously readjusts her scrunched-up underwear.
Sammy and Bob sit at lunch. Sammy is picking at her food.
You're awfully quiet.
I'm sorry.
Um... Have you thought at all about  what I said?
Of course I've been thinking about  it.
So... Any decisions? Or -- do you  still want to think about it some  more...?
Well -- I mean -- I don't know, Bob.  I mean, we haven't exactly been going  steady the last few months, if you  know what I mean --
Yeah, no, I know --
-- and then we see each other twice  and you suddenly say you want to get  married? I mean...
No, you're right, you're right --
What are you talking about?
Pause.

I don't know... I... Maybe this is...  Last year I sort of thought you were  possibly interested in that... idea...  but I was the one who, you know,  wasn't "ready" at that point -- So  that's why I thought things kind of  slowed down with us...

By far the worst.
...I don't wanna trade insults with  you.
Well, I don't want to be fired, Brian.  I've been working here for seven  years.
Well --
And if I were you I'd be a little  nervous about firing an employee I  just had an affair with. OK?
That's -- Don't threaten me, Sammy:  I'm not threatening you. I -- It's  just an area I think we should  explore.
I'm not thr -- You explore it. I'm  going back to work.
She heads for the door, stops.
Oh, and I have to pick up Rudy today  because there's no one else to do  it. But I'll find someone as soon as  I have time.
Yeah. Fine. Why don't you just take  over the whole bank?
Sammy hesitates in the doorway. This thought has never  occurred to her before. She goes out.
THROUGH THE WINDOW we see Sammy and Bob having lunch. Sam watches him eat, full of mixed feelings about him.
Sammy is at the stove, making pancakes. She puts a last  pancake onto Rudy's plate and brings it to him.
Well, I called where Uncle Terry  said he was gonna stay, and there  was no answer, so I don't know if  he's still in town or not.
Rudy doesn't answer.
Rudy? Are you not speaking to me?
Rudy doesn't answer.
Well, I'm sorry you're so mad at me,  but I only did what I thought I had  to do, and I hope you don't stay mad  at me for the rest of your life.
He opens the maple syrup and pours it on the pancakes.
Rudy, that's too much.
He keeps pouring. She grabs the bottle from him and upset some of the dishes on the table.
You gotta cut this out!
What did I do?

You don't know what you're talking  about! There was nothing else I could  do! I can't explain it better than  that, but you can't go on like this  because you don't know anything about  it and you don't know what you're  doing!
(Frightened) OK, I'm sorry!
I don't want you to be sorry, I just  want you to STOP IT!
I will! I will! I'm stopping, I'm  sorry.
He comes around the table to her.
See? I'm stopping! I'm not doing it.  See? I'm not.
He's very alarmed. Sammy looks at him for a long moment.

Terry walks through the little cemetery gate and makes hi way up the hill through the tombstones. He reaches his  parents' graves. He looks at the tombstones for a moment. puts his hand on top of one headstone, then the other. He sits down and smokes. He looks up at the SKY. It's a  beautiful deep blue sky dotted with billowy white clouds. He looks out over the hilly scenery. After a moment he sh his head a few times. He doesn't even know he's doing it. sits there.
The PHONE IS RINGING as Terry walks into the house. He wa past it, to the fridge, gets a beer and opens it. It KEEP RINGING. He picks it up.
(Into phone) Ray's house.
Sammy is at her desk on the phone.
Hi.
WE CUT BETWEEN THEM. Terry doesn't say anything.
I didn't know if you left yet.
No -- I'm leavin' tomorrow.
Well -- What time?
There's a bus at nine.
Well -- Can I -- I'd like to see you  before you go. I mean, can I give  you a lift? Or do you want to have  breakfast or anything? And I think  Rudy would really like to say good- bye.
Yeah -- I don't know... I mean --
Terry, you can't just leave like  this. I --
All right, all right. I'll come by  in the morning.
All right -- But just -- We have to  be out of the house by eight, so --  I don't want to tell Rudy you're  coming unless you really think you  can make it --
Yeah -- No -- I'll be there.
All right.
All right.
Sammy is clearing the breakfast dishes. Rudy is finishing his cereal. The clock reads 7:50.
You should get your sneakers on.
Sammy comes out and looks up and down the road.

head_text.subj: INT. LIVING ROOM. A FEW MOMENTS LATER

text: Rudy sits in the living room in his baseball jacket. His  knapsack is on the floor beside him. He looks at the CLOC 8:06. Sammy comes into the living room and looks at him.
Sweetie, I'm sorry, we have to go.
Why can't I miss school one day?
They HEAR the PICKUP PULL UP OUTSIDE, O.C. Rudy gets up  immediately.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE HOUSE. A MOMENT LATER

text: Terry jumps out of RAY'S PICKUP. Sammy opens the front do and Rudy runs out toward Terry.
Hi!
Hey, how's it goin', man?
Rudy stops short in front of Terry. Terry looks at Sammy, the doorway.
Sorry I'm late.
The car stops across the street from the BUS. The LAST KI are getting in. SAMMY HONKS for the bus driver, and Sammy Terry and Rudy all get out.
So Rudy... If I write you a letter,  will you write me back?
Yeah.
OK, well, that's gonna be pretty  nice for you, because I write a pretty  Goddamn interesting letter.
Yeah, we'll see.
All right. Well, say good-bye.
Bye.

Rudy hugs Terry. Terry hugs him back. He is suddenly over and presses his lips to the top of Rudy's head. Rudy walks to the BUS and gets on. The bus pulls away. Alone now, Sammy and Terry are not that comfortable. He m to get back in the car, and she does the same.
Sammy and Terry sit on a bench near the bus stop. Terry's backpack is by his side.
Do you need some cash for the bus?
No, I got a few bucks... Aren't you  gonna be late for work?
Oh -- Yeah. That's OK. (Pause) Terry, I don't even know where you're  going.
Oh, well, I didn't really have a  concrete plan yet. I have to go back  to Worcester and get my stuff...
Oh, are you gonna try to see that  girl?
Well... Yeah... You know... Thought  maybe I'd try to show my face... Let  her brother have a crack at me...
What?
No...
...I don't want anyone to have a  crack at you.

I'm just kidding. I just thought...  Just thought I'd check up on her... (Pause) Anyway, after that, I don't really  know. I've been thinking about Alaska  a lot. I still got some friends out  there. I don't really know. Anyway,  I'll write you.
You will?
Sure, Sammy. Of course I will. You  know that.
Pause.
What is gonna happen to you?
Nothing too bad... But I gotta tell  you, I know things didn't work out  too well this time...
Well, Terry --
...but it's always really good to  know that wherever I am, whatever  stupid shit I'm doing, you're back  at my home, rooting for me.
I do root for you.
She starts crying, and looks down.
Come on, Sammy. Everything's gonna  be all right... Comparatively... And  I'll be back this way...
I feel like I'm never gonna see you  again...!
Of course you will, Sammy. You never  have to worry about that.
Please don't go till you know where  you're going. Please...!

I do know where I'm going. I'm going  to Worcester and I'm gonna try to  see that girl. And then depending on  what happens there, I thought I'd  try to see if there's any work for  me out West. And if there is, I'm  gonna head out there for the summer  and try to make some money. And if  there isn't, I'll figure something  else out. Maybe I'll stay around the  East. I don't know... I really liked  it in Alaska. It was really beautiful.  You just -- It made me feel good.  And before things got so messed up I  was doin' pretty well out there.  Seriously. But I couldn't stay here  long, Sammy: I don't want to live  here. But I'm gonna stay in touch.  And I'll be back. 'Cause I want to  see you and I want to see Rudy. I'll  come home for Christmas. How about  that? We'll have Christmas together. (Pause) Come on, Sammy. You can trust me...
Still looking down, Sammy shakes her head, tears leaking  down her cheeks.
Come on, Sammy... Look at me... Look  at me...
She looks at him.
Hey, Sammy... Remember when we were  kids, remember what we always used  to say to each other . . .? (Pause) Remember when we were kids?
Of course I do...!
She throws her arms around his neck. He pats her gently.
The DOORS OPEN and Terry comes up the steps and into the  bus. Outside, Sammy watches him pay the driver and move  through the bus toward his seat. The BUS DOORS CLOSE.
Sammy waves till the BUS DRIVES all the way down MAIN STR turns a corner and is gone.
Terry, in his seat, turns forward and watches the view go by. He smiles a little.

The morning sunlight flickers through the windshield into the car as Sammy drives along toward work. She passes the TOWN HALL CLOCK and sees that it's 9:20. She dries her damp cheek with a forearm and rolls down he window to let the morning breeze blow through. Squaring her shoulders a little, she drives through town a slow and easy pace.
